lines.text: Fire at will!
Poor old Will, why do they always fire at him?

[unimpressed by the Fakir's performance]
Bring on the dancing girls. Get rid of this idiot!
Fakir! Off!
I've never ridden in a cart pulled by cows before.
Bullocks, Mr Belcher!
No, I haven't, honestly.

[news of the native revolt arrives]
What do you intend to do, sir?
Do? Do? We're British. We won't do anything...
...until it's too late.
Exactly. That's the first sensible thing you've said all day.
Tell Major Shorthouse to call me an elephant.
He needn't bother I'll do it. You're an elephant!
May the benevolence of the god Shivoo bring blessings on your house.
And on yours.
And may his wisdom bring success in all your undertakings.
And in yours.
And may his radiance light up your life.
And up yours.
[Sergeant-Major MacNutt has knocked Captain Keene to the floor with the spear lodged in his back]
Sergeant-Major, report to the surgeon and get that thing taken out!

[Lady Ruff Diamond has the photograph]
I must take that with me now
Then take me with it
But what about your husband?
Oh, we don't want him!
Will he not be displeased that you come away with me?
Oh, of course
[tearful]
My poor Sidney will be ever so upset!
Oh, do not worry unduly, before many days he and the others will all be dead

[happy]
Oh well, that's alright then, innit!

[brushing off a collapsed ceiling]
Oh dear! I seem to have got a little plastered!
[the Khasi's soldiers are fleeing from the kilt-lifted Third Foot and Mouth regiment]
What are you running from? There's nothing to be afraid of
[turns to look at the exposed regiment]
Ooh, I dunno though!

[McNutt and Widdle are staying behind at the pass to give the others time to retreat]
We don't fire until we see the whites of their eyes
I can see that that one has red eyes
That'll do...
Don't worry - we'll save you some Strawberry Mousse!
We need that rope of yours to get over the wall.
I'm sorry, it won't work. Not without the magic words.
Come on, you'll be well paid.
Those are the magic words! Help me of this thing!
[Keene and McNutt lift the Fakir of, to reveal empty space]
What thing?
Oh look - I've had a touch of the levitations!
[the British outpost at the Khyber Pass has been attacked]
Oh! How awful! What can have happened ?
I don't like making guesses, but I wouldn't be surprised if there hadn't been a spot of foul play here.
Foul play? Look at them! Lying around like a lot of unwanted cocktail snacks!
Ginger!
Who is?
He is. Ginger, my mate.
Private Hale ?
Yes, Ginger Hale. Hello, Ginge. It's me, Jimmy. Your old mate, Jimmy Widdle.
Jimmy? Is it you? My old mate?
Ginge, mate! How do you feel?
Oh, not so good. I think I've been wounded.
Only here and there.
Jimmy, I can trust you. Now, give it to me straight. Am I going to be all right?
Of course not, Ginge mate.
Eh?
I said, "Of course not, Ginge mate."
I'm not going to be all right?
Well, how could you be, with half a dozen dirty great holes in you? You've had it.
You're a bleeding fine mate, I must say.
What do you mean? You asked me to give it to you straight.
Yeah, but I didn't mean you to. You horrible little runt, you!
That's enough! Widdle, you're a great little comfort to a dying man, aren't you? Now listen, Hale, it's Sergeant-Major MacNutt. What happened, lad?
They attacked about a half-hour ago, Sir. Hundreds of them.
[He belches]
Burpas! They... they... oooh!
[Hale faints. Sergeant-Major MacNutt shakes his head sadly]
Oh, no! Ginge! Ginge, mate! I'm sorry, I... Poor old mate!
[Widdle gently covers Hale's body with a greatcoat. Hale throws it off]
That's right! Bleeding well suffocate me!

[watching polo game]
Ooh, I say! He did not 'alf crack that one, did he not?
Dearest, if you can't express yourself in more elegant terms, kindly shut your cakehole
[after a servant rings a gong, in the style of the famous Rank Organisation logo]
I do wish you wouldn't keep doing that. Rank stupidity!

[Watching a game of Polo in India, 1895]
Good shot! Well done, Phillip! He'll do well that boy, if he marries well...

[on the subject of underwear]
I am wearing them for sentimental reasons, sir. They were hand knitted by me mother.
I don't care if they were hand-embroidered by your father!
Well he did do the flowers.
Flowers!
They will die the death of a thousand cuts!
Oh! But that's horrible!
Not at all my little desert flower, the British are used to cuts!
Oh, Fudge!

[Evesdropping on an argument between the Ruff-Diamonds]
Makes a change from tiffin!

[Pointing to the red line Widdle is painting just inside the entrance]
What is that supposed to be, Widdle?
The thin red line - they'll never get past this!
Widdle, if you don't get out of here, I'll paint a thin red line across your thick white backside!

[looking directly at the camera]
Of course, they're all completly mad, you know!

[pulling a ladder out of the basket]
Snakes and ladders!
Then I was going to say keep a stiff upper lip.
Well I'm not standing around here waiting for mine to stiffen!
Oh what pretty earrings are they rubies!
No they are mine.
